intro: Scleranthus lepidus, commonly known as the hairy sicklegrass, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Amaranthaceae. It is characterized by its erect, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers that appear in clusters. The plant is native to Europe and parts of Asia, often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. Scleranthus lepidus is typically herbaceous and grows in a variety of habitats, including meadows and dry grasslands.
